Notes: In a further easing of restrictions Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16) were implemented on  11:59:00pm on 26 February 2021.    According to the Victorian Government COVID-19 website:   ""Face masks are no longer mandatory in schools, early childhood education and care services, and places of private study.  Face masks are mandatory for people aged 12 years and older on public transport and when in taxis or ride share vehicles.?This includes travelling to and from school on public transport or in a vehicle with others not from your household.  Face masks are strongly recommended when at least 1.5 metres distance cannot be maintained. Students under the age of 12 do not have to wear face masks.""    However, schools in Victoria are still required to follow density quotient for staff and any external visitors to the school (ie not students) of one person per two square metres when electronic record- keeping capability is in place, such as the Victorian Government QR Code Service. If electronic record- keeping is not used, a density quotient of?one person per four square metres?applies.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210308063634/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/face-masks-study-and-school  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308063714/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/education-and-training-sector-guidance     unable to archive URL for the full legal directions: Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16).

Victoria: The Workplace Directions (No 22) come into force at 11.59pm on 15 March 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No 21).According to the Victorian Government COVID-19 website:   In part, these directions state that:  “In relation to a school, non-school senior secondary provider, education and care service, childcare or early childhood service, or higher education service, spaces for the purpose of student and children use (such as classrooms, hallways and gymnasiums) are not subject to the density quotient. The density quotient does, however, still apply to spaces used only by staff (such as staff lunchrooms, photocopier room, principal’s office, back of reception and resource rooms). The density quotient also applies to any publicly accessible areas (including in relation to a school, non-school senior secondary providers, or childcare early childhood service, or higher education service)”  The density quotient is one person for every 2 square meters.    This information is up to date as of 19th March 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319070733/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2022%29%20-%2015%20March%202021.pdf

Victoria:  The Workplace Directions (No 23) come into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No 22).  “In any shared spaces (such as lunchrooms) and publicly accessible areas at the Work Premises (except in relation to any shared spaces in schools, nonschool senior secondary providers, childcare or early childhood services, or higher education services used by students or children, including classrooms, and clinical areas of a hospital), an employer must comply with the density quotient for each shared space and each publicly accessible area”    The density quotient is one person for every 2 square meters.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210326103418/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2023%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf

Victoria: In a further easing of restrictions the Victorian Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16) and Workplace Directions (No 21) came into force at 11.59pm on 26 February 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 15).  This directions remain in place as at 8th March 2021.     According to the Victorian Government COVID19 website current COVIDsafe principles for business are:   ""ensure physical distancing (1.5 metres)  wear a face mask  practise good hygiene  keep good records and act quickly if staff become unwell  avoid interactions in close spaces  create workforce bubbles""    No specific sectors are required to close in VIC.  Though, some may find it more challenging to comply with COVIDsafe requirements (for example density restrictions).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210308064855/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-work  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308065653/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2021%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308052911/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2016%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf        New South Wales:  The most recent updates to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on  Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 was made on 25th February 2021 and commencing at the beginning of 26 February 2021.  It remains current as at 8th March 2021. The direction prohibits Nightclubs operating within Greater Sydney, Central Coast, and Wollongong.  No other work places are prohibited from operating.  However, there remain capacity restriction (square meter rules and percentage capacity) and record keeping requirements.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308064217/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308064621/https://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Restrictions%20on%20Gathering%20and%20Movement%29%20Order%202021.pdf     Coded as a 2 - due to the required closing of night clubs in within Greater Sydney, Central Coast, and Wollongong.

New South Wales:  The most recent amendments to The Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 commenced on 23 March 2021.   ""The object of this Order is to amend the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 to clarify the maximum number of persons allowed on premises when the premises is being used as a nightclub and when the premises is being used for other purposes"".      However, the direction maintains that ""The Minister directs that premises in Greater Sydney must not be used as a nightclub.""    The NSW Government COVID19 website states that: ""In Greater Sydney, premises cannot operate as a nightclub (open late into the evening primarily for the purpose of providing a venue for patrons to dance), but may open to provide other services as long as the appropriate COVID-19 Safety Plan is in place, where relevant.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326104344/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx   Unable to archive the link to the legislative direction - repeatedly returning an error message. Restrictions on public gatherings remain in place in some Australian States and Territories.     Victoria: In a further easing of restrictions the Victorian Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16) and Workplace Directions (No 21) came into force at 11.59pm on 26 February 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 15).  This directions remain in place as at 8th March 2021.     According to the Victorian Government COVID19 website current COVIDsafe settings for Entertainment and culture include:   "" Indoor and outdoor seated entertainment venues can fill up to 75 per cent of seating capacity, up to a maximum of 1000 people per space. For non-seated areas, venues can use the two square metre rule if using electronic record keeping. If using paper-based records, the four square metre rule applies.  Indoor non-seated entertainment venues are limited to 50 per cent capacity, up to a maximum of 1000 people per space.  Outdoor non-seated entertainment venues are limited to the number allowed by the density quotient.  Casinos have a patron cap of 50 per cent. The four square metre rule must be applied.  Arcades, bingo centres and escape rooms are open. They must apply the two square metre rule to ensure people can keep 1.5 metre distance, provided electronic record keeping is in place. The four square metre rule applies when paper-based record keeping is in place.    Amusement parks are open, up to 75 per cent of venue capacity. They must apply the four square metre rule indoors and the two square metre rule outdoors, when using electronic record keeping. In venues using paper-based record keeping, the four square metre rule applies outdoors and indoors.  Dance floors are open in pubs, bars and nightclubs for a maximum of 50 people per dance floor, subject to the four square metre rule.  Large venues that host more than 500 people at one time must publish their COVIDSafe Plans online.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308070931/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/entertainment-and-culture  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308065653/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2021%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308052911/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2016%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf        New South Wales:  The most recent updates to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on  Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 was made on 25th February 2021 and commencing at the beginning of 26 February 2021.  It remains current as at 8th March 2021.     According to the NSW Government COVID19 government website:   “No more than 50 people can gather outside in a public place which includes public parks, reserves, beaches, public gardens and spaces.   A maximum of 300 people may attend a wedding or a funeral subject to the square metres rule applicable at the venue.  Indoor hospitality venues are generally restricted to one person per 2 square metres. For small venues, up to 25 people are allowed before the one person per 2 square metres rule applies.”  Further that “The maximum number of people that can attend a controlled outdoor event is subject to the one person per 2 square metre rule up to:  500 people if people are assigned to a seating area; or  2,000 people if the people are each assigned to a specific seat.  The event may be held in a public place that is enclosed by fencing or another form of barrier can be accessed only with a ticket. The gathering must not last longer than 5 hours.”      https://web.archive.org/web/20210308071248/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308064621/https://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Restrictions%20on%20Gathering%20and%20Movement%29%20Order%202021.pdf

Victoria and New South Wales currently have the most stringent restrictions on social gatherings.     Victoria: The Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 17) came into force at 11.59pm on 15 March 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16).  This is the most up to date direction as of the 19th March 2021.    In Victoria, groups of up to?100?people can meet in a public outdoor space from any number of households.?Children ?under 12 months of age are not included in this?limit.? An outdoor space is a park or garden in a public place outside of the home. It does not include private backyard.  Further, In Victoria, Indoor and outdoor seated entertainment venues can fill up to 75 per cent of seating capacity, up to a maximum of 1000 people per space. For non-seated areas, venues can use the two square metre rule if using electronic record keeping. If using paper-based records, the four square metre rule applies. Indoor non-seated entertainment venues are limited to 50 per cent capacity, up to a maximum of 1000 people per space    http://web.archive.org/web/20210319073955/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/entertainment-and-culture   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319072807/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/social-gatherings   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319072846/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2017%29%20-%2015%20March%202021_0.pdf     New South Wales: The Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021commenced on 11 March 2021 and remains current as of 19th march 2021.   In NSW No more than 50 people can gather outside in a public place which includes public parks, reserves, beaches, public gardens and spaces.   The maximum number of people that can attend a controlled outdoor event is subject to the one person per 2 square metre rule up to:  500 people if people are assigned to a seating area; or  2,000 people if the people are each assigned to a specific seat.  The event may be held in a public place that is enclosed by fencing or another form of barrier can be accessed only with a ticket. The gathering must not last longer than 5 hours. The organiser must have and comply with a COVID-19 Safety Plan, and electronic entry recording is compulsory.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210319071557/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney   Unable to archive the link to the full legal direction, repeatedly returned an error.

Victoria: The Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 18) came into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 17). This new direction implements a relaxing of restrictions.    In Victoria, groups of up to 200 people can meet in a public outdoor space from any number of households.  An outdoor space is a park or garden in a public place outside of the home. It does not include private backyard.    The Restricted Activity Directions (Victoria) (No 11) come into force at 6:00pm 26 March 2021 and replace the Restricted Activity Directions (No 10).  This direction provides that, In Victoria  “Seated venues (indoor and outdoor) up to 75 per cent capacity of the total venue with a maximum of 1,000 patrons in each space. Density limits apply to non-seated areas.  Non seated venues (indoor) up to 75 per cent of capacity, with a maximum of 1000 patrons in each space. Density limits apply.  Non seated venues (outdoor) do not have patron caps but density limits apply  No cap on dance floors. Density limits apply, depending on the venue type.  Casinos to 75 per cent of venue capacity.  Removal of gaming machine caps.  All venues must use the Government QR Code Service, or API linked digital system, to maintain electronic record keeping.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326111234/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28No%2018%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326111931if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326112159/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Restricted%20Activity%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2011%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf     New South Wales: The Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 directs that as of 26th march 2021.   In NSW No more than 50 people can gather outside in a public place which includes public parks, reserves, beaches, public gardens and spaces.   The maximum number of people that can attend a controlled outdoor event is subject to the one person per 2 square metre rule up to:  500 people if people are assigned to a seating area; or  2,000 people if the people are each assigned to a specific seat.  The event may be held in a public place that is enclosed by fencing or another form of barrier can be accessed only with a ticket. The gathering must not last longer than 5 hours. The organiser must have and comply with a COVID-19 Safety Plan, and electronic entry recording is compulsory.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210326112437/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney    Unable to archive the link to the full legal direction, repeatedly returned an error.

Currently Victoria and New South Wales have the most stringent government directions restricting private gatherings.     Victoria: In a further easing of restrictions the Victorian Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16) came into force at 11.59pm on 26 February 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 15).  This directions remain in place as at 8th March 2021.     According to the Victorian Government COVID19 website current COVIDsafe settings for Social gatherings include:   You can have up to 30 visitors to your home per day, meaning the household members plus 30 visitors (children under 12 months of age and intimate partners of any person living in your house do not count towards the 30-person cap).    If you have visitors in your home, it is strongly recommended that face masks are worn during the visit.    Face masks are also strongly recommended if you cannot keep 1.5 metres distance from others (except if you are with household members or an intimate partner   If you are planning to leave your home – you must carry a face mask.   You can meet in groups of up to 100 people in a public outdoor space from any number of households.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308071910/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/social-gatherings  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308065653/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2021%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308052911/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2016%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf        New South Wales:  The most recent updates to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 was made on 25th February 2021 and commencing at the beginning of 26 February 2021.  It remains current as at 8th March 2021.     According to the NSW Government COVID19 government website:   “Up to 50 visitors from any number of households may visit another at any one time. Under the rules  the total number of visitors includes adults and children  a member of the hosting household is not counted as a visitor  an overnight stay as part of a visit to someone’s house is allowed.  …If there are more than 50 visitors at a home, every person will be held individually responsible for a breach of the public health order.”      https://web.archive.org/web/20210308071248/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308064621/https://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Restrictions%20on%20Gathering%20and%20Movement%29%20Order%202021.pdf

New South Wales:   According to the NSW Government Transport website on the19th march 2021.   “To help you maintain physical distancing measures on the network, we are:  Tracking passenger numbers in near real-time to help manage customer flow and crowding.  Increasing public transport services where capacity and resources are available.  Controlling access to platforms, stations and interchanges to help manage physical distancing where necessary.  Rolling out green physical distance capacity stickers across all modes to provide guidance.  Deploying extra staff at stations, interchanges, wharves and stops to assist customers with physical distancing as they move through the network. These marshals will also be available to assist any customer with visual impairments or any other disability.  Physical distancing onboard capacity guidelines  To maintain physical distancing on public transport, capacity restrictions are in place. The number of seats available per travel mode are shown below.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305111251/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance   https://web.archive.org/web/20210319053029/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/border-restrictions/public-transport   Facemasks are also mandated on NSW public transport, according to the NSW Government Transport website and up to date as at the 19th march 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210319053125/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/face-masks     Victoria:   The Victorian Government Public Transport Victoria website states on 19th March 2021 that face masks are compulsory on public transport in Victoria.  There is also a recommendation and financial incentive for commuters to travel outside peak hours.  “Travel outside peak times when there are less people on the network. On weekdays get a 30% off peak discount on metropolitan services or travel free before 7.15am on metropolitan trains.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319051859/https://www.ptv.vic.gov.au/more/coronavirus-covid-19/     Queensland:   The Queensland Government Public Transport website states encourages travellers to physically distance while travelling and to travel at of peak times.  However, there does not appear to be any requirement to do so.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210319052936/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/help-and-advice/public-transport     Western Australia:   The Western Australian Government Transperth website states on 19th march 2021   “To help prevent the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus) we are asking passengers to follow medical advice and:  Stay home if you are sick  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, before and after using public transport, after going to the bathroom, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing. Or clean with an alcohol-based hand sanitiser  Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands  Additionally if you are travelling on a bus you will need to use the front door to pay for your trip, however, to reduce contact between passengers and bus drivers, we are asking you to exit via the rear doors unless you require the front doors for low floor access.  Physical distancing – Although public transport and associated stations and platforms are exempt from physical distancing recommendations, transport staff and passengers are still encouraged to maintain physical distancing where possible.  If you suspect you may have COVID-19 symptoms or may have had close contact with a person who has COVID-19, you should call the National Coronavirus Helpline on 1800 020 080. For all other COVID-19 enquiries please call 13COVID.”  No significant COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210319054513/https://www.transperth.wa.gov.au/Using-Transperth/coronavirus-advice   Tasmania:   The Tasmanian Government COVID-19 website on 19th March that “Passengers are encouraged to keep physical distancing in mind and choose a seat away from others where possible….anyone feeling unwell should avoid using public transport. For short trips, consider walking or cycling. Travel outside peak periods where possible. While waiting at bus stops, practice social distancing. Adults seeking to board a bus which has a high number of passengers are asked to consider waiting for the next service where available. This request does not apply to children.”  No significant COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210319054356/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/transport         Northern Territory:   The Northern Territory government COVID-19 website on the 19th march 2021 states that “Public transport, including buses, taxis and rideshare services, continues to operate in the Northern Territory (NT). To minimise the risk of contracting or spreading coronavirus (COVID-19), passengers must practice good hygiene and physical distancing where possible.”  No significant COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210319055612/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/public-transport     Australian Capital Territory:   The Australian Capital Territory Government Website site states on 19th March 2021, that “Almost 700 more services have been introduced each weekday and more than 200 services each Saturday, to help you spread out your travel… Use of public transport during off peak times is encouraged where possible. This helps with physical distancing onboard and at stops and stations. Off peak travel is also cheaper.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210319060642/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/community/transport

As of the 8th March 2021,  Western Australia is the only state or territory that is restricting inter/intra state movement as a response to COVID-19. According to the WA COVID-19 government website the whole of Victoria is deemed 'low risk'. Travellers from 'low risk' areas must  ""If you have suitable premises, enter self-quarantine for 14 days. If not, you will be directed to enter a Government-approved quarantine facility at your own expense for 14 days.  You must present for a COVID-19 test on Day 11 if still in WA"".     Some remote Aboriginal Communities in WA remain closed to visitors as a policy response to COVID-19.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308073403/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-interstate-border  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308073909/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308073934/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/publications/restrictions-travel-remote-aboriginal-communities-frequently-asked-questions

As of the 12th March 2021,  Western Australia remains the only state or territory that is restricting inter/intra state movement as a response to COVID-19. According to the WA COVID-19 government website the whole of Victoria is deemed 'low risk'. Travellers from 'low risk' areas must  ""If you have suitable premises, enter self-quarantine for 14 days. If not, you will be directed to enter a Government-approved quarantine facility at your own expense for 14 days.  You must present for a COVID-19 test on Day 11 if still in WA"".     Some remote Aboriginal Communities in WA remain closed to visitors as a policy response to COVID-19.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210312065304/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-interstate-border#lr  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215012302/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel

Effective 12.01am, Monday, March 15 Western Australia relaxed its interstate boarder restrictions, allowing Victorians to enter Western Australia without quarantine.    On the 15th March 2021 there are no interstate boarder restrictions within Australia.   However, within Western Australia, a significant number of remote Aboriginal Communities remain closed to visitors as a policy response to COVID-19.   Under the WA Government’s Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  •	providing essential services and supplies  •	going to work or school there  •	entering for family or cultural reasons  •	delivering a community program or activity  •	entering in an emergency.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210312065853/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel  http://web.archive.org/web/20210319075422/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-08/Remote%20Aboriginal%20Communities%20Directions%20%28No.%203%29.pdf     Coded as a 1T, to recognise that while travel restrictions within WA remain in place – there are reasonably broad exceptions.  For example, you are allowed to enter a community if you work there, visiting family, or attending a cultural activity.

Up to date as of 8th March 2021: There remains additional restrictions on travellers that have been to New Zealand.    According to the Australian Government Department of Home Affairs website: The following additional requirements are in place for some travellers seeking to travel on quarantine-free flights from New Zealand to Australia.          ""From Thursday 25 February 2021 any traveller from New Zealand, who has been in Auckland (except for Auckland airport for the purpose of travelling only) during the previous 14-days before their scheduled flight, is not eligible to travel on a quarantine-free (green zone) flight.      Any travellers from New Zealand who have not been in Auckland for any period over the previous 14-days are still eligible to travel on a quarantine-free (green zone) flight.      Routine pre-departure and on arrival screening will continue.""   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308035029/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/new-zealand-safe-travel-zone

In a modest easing of restrictions The Australian Government Home Affairs website states that ""From 11:59pm AEDT on 11 March 2021, quarantine-free flights from New Zealand to Australia will resume. ""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312070503/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/new-zealand-safe-travel-zone    Other than quarantine-free flights from New Zealand, Australia's boarders are closed to non-citizens (with very limited exception). Full details can be read at link below to the Australian Government Home Affairs website.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312070401/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions

As published on the Australian Government Services Australia Website and the Australian Government business.gov.au website - current at 19th march 2021 - The JobKeeper Payment is a scheme to support businesses and not-for-profit organisations significantly affected by COVID-19, to help keep more Australians in jobs. The JobKeeper Payment is administered by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The JobKeeper Payment will be available to eligible businesses (including the self-employed) and not-for-profits until 28 March 2021.  The JobKeeper Payment rates for this extension period are: Tier 1: $1,000 per fortnight (before tax) Tier 2: $650 per fortnight (before tax).      http://web.archive.org/web/20210319082827/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/if-you-get-income-from-jobkeeper-payment-during-coronavirus-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319083345/https://www.ato.gov.au/General/JobKeeper-Payment/Payment-rates/   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319083327/https://business.gov.au/risk-management/emergency-management/coronavirus-information-and-support-for-business/jobkeeper-payment     Furthermore the Australian Government Services Australia Website- current as at the 19th March 2021 – states that “You may be able to get the Coronavirus Supplement if you get at least $1 of an eligible income support payment. The temporary Coronavirus Supplement is available at a rate of $150 per fortnight until 31 March 2021.”  “You’ll automatically get the supplement if you’re getting 1 of the following payments:  •	JobSeeker Payment  •	Partner Allowance  •	Widow Allowance  •	Youth Allowance  •	Austudy  •	ABSTUDY Living Allowance  •	Parenting Payment  •	Farm Household Allowance  •	Special Benefit.”  http://web.archive.org/web/20210319083644/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/coronavirus-supplement   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319083728/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/coronavirus-supplement/who-can-get-it

The below note made on the 26th Feb remains up to date as of 26th March 2021.  I have included updated links here.      Currently, as at the 26th March 2021, each state and territory has somewhat different household level debt and contact relief COVID-19 Reponses in place.  However, the only type of COVID-19 related household relief that appears to apply across all jurisdictions is in relation to residential rental payments and/or contracts.     ACT:   According to the ACT government website, and current as at 26th March 2021: The annual increase will not be applied to 2020-2021 annual rates bills, The ACT Revenue Office will implement a new process for rates deferrals for owner occupiers experiencing hardship because of COVID-19. No interest will apply to the deferred amount, The Government is providing land tax and rates rebates to landlords of residential properties who reduce rents by at least 25 per cent for tenants impacted by COVID-19, The ACT Government is offering stamp duty concessions in the ACT for some home buyers planning to live in their new property, All 2020-21 vehicle registration, parking and public transport fee increases at the current levels., Households already receiving the Utilities Concession will receive an additional $200 rebate through their electricity bill, The government will freeze the Utilities Network Facilities Tax (UNFT) at the current  level.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102021/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/business-and-work/economic-survival-package/families-and-households   NSW:  According to the ACT government website, and current as at 26th March 2021: measures to restrict when landlords can evict tenants due to rental arrears as a result of COVID-19;   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326101357/https://www.fairtrading.nsw.gov.au/resource-library/publications/coronavirus-covid-19/property/moratorium   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326101958/https://www.nsw.gov.au/life-events     QLD:   According to the QLD government website, and current as at 26th March 2021:   There remain some temporary regulatory measures to 30 April 2021 means Queensland remains ready to respond to COVID-19 risks as the transition back to normal residential tenancy arrangements continues.  These are: provisions allowing tenants experiencing domestic and family violence to end their tenancies quickly; protections for tenants against being listed in a tenancy database for rent arrears caused by COVID-19 impacts; limits on reletting costs for eligible tenants who end their fixed term tenancies early; short term tenancy statement extensions for moveable dwellings; entry restrictions and requirements to support COVID-19 social distancing measures; relaxed repair and maintenance obligations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210326102104/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/the-hub/covid-19-tenancy-update    VIC:   According to The Victorian Government website, and current as at 26th March 2021, COVID-19 changes to renting laws (implemented 29 March 2020 and still in effect) mean that tenants in financial hardship cannot be given a notice to vacate; landlords must try to negotiated a temporary rent reduction agreement where it is needed by tenants because of the impacts of COVID-19. Tenants can apply for a rent relief grant of up to $3,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102308/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/renting-laws-and-support-during-coronavirus-covid-19-pandemic    NT:  According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 26th March 2021 “On 24 April 2020, the Northern Territory Parliament passed the Tenancies Legislation Amendment Act 2020. This provides the framework for the Territory’s response to tenancy issues arising as a result of the COVID-19 emergency.” These modifications: Extending notice timeframes for certain pre termination actions under the Act; establish New processes for termination of a tenancy; and provide for modified entry and inspection processes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102313/https://consumeraffairs.nt.gov.au/rental-changes-due-to-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102331/https://nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/818308/s28.pdf    WA: According to The Western Australian Government website, and current as at 26th March 2021” “In response to COVID-19, the Western Australian Government implemented a moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases, under the Residential Tenancies (COVID-19 Response) Act 2020. The extended emergency period ends on 28 March 2021, which means that all the existing laws will stay in place until this date, after which the ordinary tenancy laws will apply again.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102604/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response   SA:  According to SA Government COVID-19 website, and current as at 26th March 2021 “State Parliament has endorsed a number of initiatives aimed at helping landlords and tenants whose incomes have been affected by COVID-19.” This includes “Ensuring tenants cannot be evicted by landlords due to an inability to paid rent because of COVID-19 employment loss”.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102653/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/school-and-community/housing-and-in-the-community    TA:   According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 26th March 2021.  “Some of the changes to the Residential Tenancy Act 1997 including changes to rental evictions, rental increases, and general repairs and maintenance expired on 31 January 2021.” However, The Tasmanian Government is providing rent relief for residential households who rent homes in the private market and who are experiencing housing stress because of the impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19).  The Support Funds are available until 31 March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102826/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/rental-housing

In an easing of restrictions the Victorian Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 16) came into force at 11.59pm on 26 February 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 15).  This directions remain in place as at 8th March 2021.   According to the VIC Govt. COVID-19 government website, directions require that:   “You must always carry a face mask with you at all times when you leave the home, unless you have a lawful reason not to.  Face masks must be worn:  on public transport, in commercial passenger vehicles such as taxis and ride share vehicles, and in tour vehicles  by visitors to a hospital  by visitors at a care facility (while indoors)  indoors at shopping centres, retail facilities with 2,000 or more square metres of indoor space, markets and market stalls  on flights to and from Victoria and  at airports  if you are diagnosed or suspected of having COVID-19, or a close contact of someone diagnosed with COVID-19, when leaving your home or accommodation for a permitted reason, such as medical care or to get tested  while awaiting the results of a COVID-19 test when leaving your home or accommodation for a permitted reason, such as medical care (except as part of a surveillance or other asymptomatic testing program)  while experiencing any symptoms of COVID-19.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224152432if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/face-masks-when-wear-face-mask  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308052911/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2016%29%20-%2026%20February%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf       Victoria currently has the highest level face mask regulations in Australia.   However, this item has been coded as a 2G because Victoria’s restrictions no longer meet criteria to be coded at the level of a 3 AND every state and territory requires that face masks are worn on airplanes and airports as a minimum.    New South Wales:   “On 12 February the Minister signed the Public Health (COVID-19 Mandatory Face Coverings) Amendment (No 4) Order 2021 (Amending Order).    The Amending Order amends the Public Health (COVID-19 Mandatory Face Coverings) Order 2021 to only require a mask to be worn:  on public transport (including taxis and ride share) and public transport waiting areas in Greater Sydney (including the Blue Mountains, Wollongong and the Central Coast)  at airports  on domestic commercial aircraft that land at, or take off from, a NSW airport while in NSW”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308053138/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx     Queensland:   “To protect the health of Queenslanders, from 12am AEST 12 January 2021 wearing of a face mask will be mandatory in particular settings anywhere in Queensland… You must carry a face mask while in a Queensland airport and wear it at all times… You must wear a face mask at all times if you are on a domestic commercial flight while the plane is at a Queensland airport and in Queensland airspace… You must wear a face mask while transporting a person required to quarantine on a bus, coach service, taxi or ride-share to or from government hotels… If you are arriving to Queensland from overseas or a COVID-19 hotspot and you are required to quarantine, you must wear a face mask while travelling from the airport on a bus, coach service, taxi or ride-share to your quarantine hotel. You must wear the mask until you arrive at your allocated room in government arranged accommodation.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308053358/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/public-health-directions/mandatory-masks   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308053441/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/mandatory-masks     Western Australia:   “Wearing a face mask is mandatory in the following settings:  in an airport in WA  on an aircraft in WA or  travelling in a vehicle with a person who is subject to a quarantine direction (this includes personal vehicles, private cars, hired cars, ride-share vehicles or taxis).”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226053120/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do       Tasmania:   “you must wear a mask when:    inside or outside an airport terminal. This includes saying goodbye and greeting passengers (unless you stay in your car);  on board your flight (including during boarding and disembarking, while flying, and when you are on the tarmac); and  whilst waiting for your transport or walking to or from your transport (including in the car park).”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308054208/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/keeping-yourself-safe/facemasks   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226143610/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0038/139979/Airports-and-aircrafts-No.-2-5-Feb-21.pdf     Northern Territory:   “Chief Health Officer Directions make it mandatory for face masks to be worn at all major NT airports and while on board an aircraft. Masks must be worn when inside the airport and when on the airfield.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308054704/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0009/965628/cho-directions-no1-2021-wearing-face-masks-in-aircraft-and-airports.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308054727/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/information-about-face-masks   Australian Capital Territory:   ‘Under a public health direction effective from 11.59pm on Friday 22 January 2021, face masks are mandatory for people aged 12 and over, including workers who interact with the public, while inside the Canberra Airport terminal and during domestic commercial flights in and out of Canberra.  Although face masks are not required to be worn outside the terminal of Canberra Airport, passengers embarking and disembarking a flight on the tarmac must keep them on.’  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308055258/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/stay-safe-and-healthy/protect-yourself   URL for from legal direction ‘Public Health (Mandatory Face Masks –Canberra Airport and Domestic Flights) Emergency Direction 2021’ unable to be archived.

Currently, as at 12 March 2021, Australia remains at in phase 1a of the COVIC-19 Vaccination delivery strategy.  The following groups are receiving the vaccine: Quarantine, border and [COVID-19] front line health care workers; Aged care and disability care staff; and Aged care and disability care residents.    The Two groups coded as currently receiving the vaccine are A - Key workers and C - Elderly groups.    All phase 1a vaccinations are with the Pfizer vaccine only.      According to the Australian Government Department of Health website 86369 vaccinations had been given as at 7 March 2021.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210312072437/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312072512/https://covid-vaccine.healthdirect.gov.au/eligibility  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312072659/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19

The Hon Greg Hunt MP Minister for Health and Aged Care announced in a media release on 22nd March 2021 that ""Today is a momentous day for Australia’s fight against COVID-19, with the rollout of Phase 1B of the Australian Government’s vaccination plan."" ...  ""Priority groups in Phase 1B include:    elderly adults aged 80 years and over  elderly adults aged 70 years and over  health care workers not vaccinated in Phase 1A  Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 55  adults with a specified medical condition  adults with a severe disability who have a specified underlying medical condition  critical and high risk workers including defence, police, fire, emergency services and meat processing.""  The COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in Australia.    Both the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine and the Oxford/Astrazeneca vaccine are in use for phase 1B.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090223/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/phase-1b-covid-19-vaccination-rollout-begins   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090708/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090821/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/which-covid-19-vaccine-will-i-receive

In an easing of restrictions, and according to the Victorian Government Covid19 website, Victoria returned to COVIDSafe settings from 11:59pm Friday 26 February 2021.  As a result, while facilitates may introduce their own restrictions, state government law now provides that there are no limits on the purpose of visits, the number of visitors or the length of the visit to care facilities.    However, workers and visitors to ages care facilities must make a declaration prior to entry; that they do not have COVID-19 symptoms; have not been in contact with a confirmed case, are not currently required to quarantine/isolate, and they have not been overseas within the last 14 days.   Masks must be worn when visiting an aged care facility.   Care facilities must comply with the two square metre rule that limits the number of people that can be in a shared communal space at the same time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308040807/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/visiting-care-facilities     All other states and territories have some narrow precautions/restrictions for visitation to residential aged care facilities.  Therefore this item has been changed from a 3T to a 2G.     New South Wales:   As of the 25th Feb 2021 and current at 8th march 2021, according to the NSW Government Health website “There are no restrictions on the number of visitors a resident can have each day or at any one time.”  Further “Visitors to a facility in NSW are not required to wear a surgical mask.  Exclude visitors who:  have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  have been to any NSW, Interstate or Overseas locations listed in the current areas of concern at the dates and times listed for 14 days after they have visited the location  live in the NSW areas of increased testing  are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  are waiting for a COVID-19 test result.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308042537/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx       Queensland:   According to the QLD Government Health website: “Visitors, staff or volunteers at a residential aged care facility should not be anyone who:    is unwell  has been diagnosed with COVID-19 or asked to quarantine  has returned from overseas in the last 14 days (excluding safe travel zone countries)  has had contact with a person with COVID-19 in the last 14 days  has visited a COVID-19 hotspot in the last 14 days or since the hotspot was declared (whichever is shorter)  has been tested for COVID-19 and is waiting for the result (except for tests due to surveillance testing obligations)  has COVID-19 symptoms of fever (37.5 degrees or more), cough, shortness of breath, sore throat, loss of smell or taste, runny nose, diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting or fatigue  You may enter a residential aged care facility if you do not fit into any of the above categories.  Visitors should:  wash their hands before entering and leaving the facility  stay 1.5 metres away from others where possible  follow requests from the facility to help keep staff and residents safe.”  This is also in accordance with the Aged Care Direction (No. 24) which was implemented  9.45am AEST 20 February 2021 and remain in effect.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308043220/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/public-health-directions/aged-care   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308043223/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/aged-care     Western Australia:   According to the WA Government COVID19 website “To help protect people in aged care, family members can visit residents, but some additional restrictions are in place.  You should not visit if you have:   returned from overseas in the last 14 days  been in contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days  a fever or symptoms of acute respiratory infection (e.g. cough, sore throat, runny nose, shortness of breath)  not had an up-to-date influenza vaccination.  Additionally, quarantine centre workers must wear a face mask and keep 1.5 metres away from other people when visiting residential aged care facilities.  “  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226053120/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do  This is also in accordance with the WA VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES  DIRECTIONS (NO 7) which were implemented at 11.59 p.m. on 23rd February 2021 and remain in effect.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308041835/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/240221-Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Directions-No7.pdf     Tasmania:   Public Health Act 1997 DIRECTION UNDER SECTION 16 (Residential Aged Care Facilities - No. 10). In place since and 26 October 2020 and still current.  People may not enter an aged care facility if they: have been outside of Tasmania in a place that the Tasmanian Director of Public Health determines in medium or high risk; has any clinical symptoms of COVID-19; does not have an up-to-date influenza vaccination.  There are exceptions to these rules for end of life visits.  Care and Support visits are limited to 2 people at one time (unless preapproved for a larger number) and must be held in a non-communal area of the facility.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117231413/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/126294/Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-No.-10-24-Oct-20.pdf     Northern Territory:   According to the Northern Territory Government COVID19 website:   “You must not enter or remain on the premises:  if you have  symptoms that are consistent with coronavirus (COVID-19)  a body temperature higher than 37.5 degrees  coughing, sore throat, fatigue, shortness of breath or other symptoms of respiratory illness  you do not have an up-to-date vaccination against influenza  this does not apply if you have a medical contraindication to the vaccine  you have been in contact with a person with coronavirus (COVID-19).”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210303123611/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/advice-care/residential-aged-care   Also see full legal direction ‘COVID-19 Directions (No. 40) 2020 Directions for Aged Care Facilities ’ here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308050912/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/898953/cho-directions-no40-directions-aged-care-facilities.pdf     Australian Capital Territory:   According to the ACT Government COVID-19 website:   “However, you cannot visit aged care facilities if you:  Have returned from overseas in the last 14 days.  Have been in a geographical area of risk in the last 14 days.  Have been in contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days.  Have a temperature higher than 37.5 degrees or history of fever (e.g. night sweats or chills).  Symptoms of a respiratory infection such as a cough, sore throat, shortness of breath, loss of smell or loss of taste.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308050101/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/stay-safe-and-healthy/aged-care/advice-for-visitors-to-aged-care-facilities   URL for full legal direction ‘Public Health (Residential Aged Care Facilities) Emergency Direction 2021 (No2)’ unable to be archived.

1st March 2021, in a modest easing of restrictions, Tasmania changed some restrictions around visiting residential aged care facilities. From the beginning of Monday 1 March 2021 the Direction No. 11 for Residential Aged Care Facilities came into effect.  The TAS government COVID19 website states:   “In Tasmania, visits to residential aged care facilities are permitted for people providing care and support, with the following restrictions:  Visitors must not have any symptoms of COVID-19, including fever (a temperature higher than 37.5 degrees), symptoms of fever (chills, night sweats), cough, sore throat, shortness of breath or loss of taste or smell.  Unless an exemption has been granted (see below) visitors must not be in quarantine. That means they must not have:  been in an area or premises identified as medium or high-risk for COVID-19 in the previous 14 days  had contact with anyone known to have COVID-19, or reasonably suspected of having COVID-19, within the previous 14 days (except as part of their employment while wearing effective personal protective equipment).  Operators of aged care facilities must screen all people (except people attending for emergency management reasons) before they enter the premises. See the Staff/Visitor Screening Tool for Residential Care Services  Operators of aged care facilities are required to record the contact details for everyone who remains on site for 15 minutes or more. This includes the name, telephone number and date/time of entry for every person who visits. This is to support rapid contact tracing if someone associated with the facility gets COVID-19. Contact information can be recorded using the Check-in Tas app.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308044437/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/aged-care-facility-visits   Also see full legal direction (Residential Aged Care Facilities - No. 11) here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308045737/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/126294/Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-No.-11.pdf     Code remains at 2G.

Code changed on the 26th March 2021.  Code changed from 2G to 2T.  This changed was made because New South Wales repealed The Public Health (COVID-19 Aged Care Facilities) Order (No 4) 2020 and amended to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order whereby the Minister directs an operator of a residential aged care facility must consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer.  This change in legislative direction means that and restrictions applying to specifically to residential aged care facilities in NSW are now recommend rather than mandatory.     New South Wales:   Up to date on the 26th March 2021, the NSW Government COVID-19 website states that “The Public Health (COVID-19 Aged Care Facilities) Order (No 4) 2020 was repealed from 12:01am 11 March 2021. Residential aged care facilities are now required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements. Individual operators may choose to implement their own decisions about access restrictions and screening requirements, having regard to the advice of the Chief Health Officer. An amendment to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order whereby the Minister directs an operator of a residential aged care facility must consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in relation to:  management of visitors  screening of staff and visitors  arrangements for group recreation and other activities for residents  wearing of face masks by staff and visitors  vaccinations against influenza and COVID-19.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326073848/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx     The current advice of the Chief Health Officer is that:  “There are no current areas of increased testing. When applicable, visitors should not enter unless they are providing essential care to residents or for compassionate reasons.  Visitors to a facility in NSW are not required to wear a surgical mask but must meet all screening criteria.  Exclude visitors who:  have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  have been to any NSW, Interstate or New Zealand locations listed in the current areas of concern at the dates and times listed for 14 days after they have visited the location  live in the NSW areas of increased testing  are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  are waiting for a COVID-19 test result.”  “At outings and excursions attended by residents ensure that:  •	the event complies with the current Gathering and Movement Public Health Order  •	no one at the event:  •	have been to any NSW, Interstate or New Zealand locations listed in the current areas of concern at the dates and times listed for 14 days after they have visited the location  •	lives in the NSW areas of increased testing  •	has been a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  •	lives in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  •	is waiting for a COVID-19 test result.”    And “Staff working in a facility in NSW are not required to wear a surgical mask unless a staff member has been in Brisbane City the Moreton Bay Council areas.  Exclude staff who:  •	have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  •	have visited any locations of concern in Queensland  •	 are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  •	live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  •	are waiting for a COVID-19 test result”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326074730/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx

Coded as 3T due to implementation of COVID-19 restrictions applying to residential aged care facilities in QLD.     New South Wales:   Up to date on the 26th March 2021, the NSW Government COVID-19 website states that “The Public Health (COVID-19 Aged Care Facilities) Order (No 4) 2020 was repealed from 12:01am 11 March 2021. Residential aged care facilities are now required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements. Individual operators may choose to implement their own decisions about access restrictions and screening requirements, having regard to the advice of the Chief Health Officer. An amendment to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order whereby the Minister directs an operator of a residential aged care facility must consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in relation to:  management of visitors  screening of staff and visitors  arrangements for group recreation and other activities for residents  wearing of face masks by staff and visitors  vaccinations against influenza and COVID-19.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326073848/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx     The current advice of the Chief Health Officer is that:  “There are no current areas of increased testing. When applicable, visitors should not enter unless they are providing essential care to residents or for compassionate reasons.  Visitors to a facility in NSW are not required to wear a surgical mask but must meet all screening criteria.  Exclude visitors who:  have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  have been to any NSW, Interstate or New Zealand locations listed in the current areas of concern at the dates and times listed for 14 days after they have visited the location  live in the NSW areas of increased testing  are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  are waiting for a COVID-19 test result.”  “At outings and excursions attended by residents ensure that:  •	the event complies with the current Gathering and Movement Public Health Order  •	no one at the event:  •	have been to any NSW, Interstate or New Zealand locations listed in the current areas of concern at the dates and times listed for 14 days after they have visited the location  •	lives in the NSW areas of increased testing  •	has been a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  •	lives in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  •	is waiting for a COVID-19 test result.”    And “Staff working in a facility in NSW are not required to wear a surgical mask unless a staff member has been in Brisbane City the Moreton Bay Council areas.  Exclude staff who:  •	have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  •	have visited any locations of concern in Queensland  •	 are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  •	live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  •	are waiting for a COVID-19 test result”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326074730/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx   Victoria:   The Care Facilities Directions (No 25) come into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Care Facilities Directions (No 24).   These directions do identify some individuals that should be excluded from entering aged care facilities.  These are if:   “(a) the person is required to self-isolate under the Diagnosed Persons and Close Contacts Directions; or  (b) the person is required to self-quarantine under the Diagnosed Persons and Close Contacts Directions; or  (c) during the 14 days immediately preceding the entry, the person arrived in Australia from a place outside Australia other than a person arriving on a quarantine-free flight from an overseas location designated by the Australian Government as a green travel zone; or  (d) during the 14 days immediately preceding the entry, the person had known contact with a confirmed case (except in the course of their employment while wearing the appropriate level of personal protective equipment in the circumstances); or  (e) the person has SARS-CoV-2 Symptoms; or Note: for the purposes of these directions, SARS-CoV-2 Symptoms, including but not limited to acute respiratory infection (such as cough, shortness of breath, sore throat); loss of smell; and loss of taste do not include those symptoms where caused by an underlying health condition or medication.  (f) in the case of a visitor—the person has been tested for SARS-CoV-2, and has not yet received the results of that test.”  However, there is some limited exception to these limitations in end of life circumstances and with the permission of the chief health officer and director of the facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326080338/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Care%20Facilities%20Directions%20%28No%2025%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf     Queensland:   According to the QLD Government’s COVID 19 website, from midday 26th March, restrictions for visitors to residential aged care facilities located in the city of Brisbane and the Moreton Bay Region have been increased.    “These restrictions include:  No personal visitors – including care and support visitors – are allowed to enter  Only people providing an essential purpose will be allowed to enter  End of life visits will still be allowed  Anyone entering a facility must wear a single use surgical face mask  Residents May only leave the facility to receive health care, attend a funeral or for an emergency or compassionate reason.”  The Aged Care Direction (No. 25) provides the legal framework for this restriction.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326082208/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/aged-care   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326082923/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/contact-tracing   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326082208/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/aged-care     Western Australia:   According to the WA Government COVID19 website “To help protect people in aged care, family members can visit residents, but some additional restrictions are in place. You should not visit if you have:   returned from overseas in the last 14 days  been in contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days  a fever or symptoms of acute respiratory infection (e.g. cough, sore throat, runny nose, shortness of breath)  not had an up-to-date influenza vaccination.  Additionally, quarantine centre workers must wear a face mask and keep 1.5 metres away from other people when visiting residential aged care facilities.  “  This is also in accordance with the WA VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES DIRECTIONS (NO 7) which were implemented at 11.59 p.m. on 23rd February 2021 and remain in effect.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326083229/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do   https://web.archive.org/web/20210318010614/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/240221-Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Directions-No7.pdf     Tasmania:   The Direction No. 11 for Residential Aged Care Facilities has been in place from the start of Monday 1 March 2021.   According to the Tasmanian Government COVID-19 website   “In Tasmania, visits to residential aged care facilities are permitted for people providing care and support, with the following restrictions:  Visitors must not have any symptoms of COVID-19, including fever (a temperature higher than 37.5 degrees), symptoms of fever (chills, night sweats), cough, sore throat, shortness of breath or loss of taste or smell.  …visitors must not be in quarantine. That means they must not have:  been in an area or premises identified as medium or high-risk for COVID-19 in the previous 14 days  had contact with anyone known to have COVID-19, or reasonably suspected of having COVID-19, within the previous 14 days (except as part of their employment while wearing effective personal protective equipment).  Operators of aged care facilities must screen all people (except people attending for emergency management reasons) before they enter the premises. See the Staff/Visitor Screening Tool for Residential Care Services  Operators of aged care facilities are required to record the contact details for everyone who remains on site for 15 minutes or more. This includes the name, telephone number and date/time of entry for every person who visits. This is to support rapid contact tracing if someone associated with the facility gets COVID-19. Contact information can be recorded using the Check-in Tas app”  There are very limited exemptions to these restrictions for end of life circumstance.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312140806/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/126294/Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-No.-11.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326083936/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/aged-care-facility-visits     Northern Territory:   According to the Northern Territory Government COVID19 website:   “You must not enter or remain on the premises:  if you have  symptoms that are consistent with coronavirus (COVID-19)  a body temperature higher than 37.5 degrees  coughing, sore throat, fatigue, shortness of breath or other symptoms of respiratory illness  you do not have an up-to-date vaccination against influenza  this does not apply if you have a medical contraindication to the vaccine  you have been in contact with a person with coronavirus (COVID-19).”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308050522/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/advice-care/residential-aged-care     Also see full legal direction ‘COVID-19 Directions (No. 40) 2020 Directions for Aged Care Facilities ’ here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210326084231/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/898953/cho-directions-no40-directions-aged-care-facilities.pdf       Australian Capital Territory:   According to the ACT Government COVID-19 website:   “However, you cannot visit aged care facilities if you:  Have returned from overseas in the last 14 days.  Have been in a geographical area of risk in the last 14 days.  Have been in contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days.  Have a temperature higher than 37.5 degrees or history of fever (e.g. night sweats or chills).  Symptoms of a respiratory infection such as a cough, sore throat, shortness of breath, loss of smell or loss of taste.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326084442/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/stay-safe-and-healthy/aged-care/advice-for-visitors-to-aged-care-facilities  URL for full legal direction ‘Public Health (Residential Aged Care Facilities) Emergency Direction 2021 (No2)’ unable to be archived.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210326084545/https://www.legislation.act.gov.au/ni/2021-56/

Social distancing and other public measures in restaurants and cafes remain in place. Cinemas are only allowed to operate at 80% capacity.    ""1. Operators or operators of food premises are required to procure  Bruhealth QR codes specific to their premises and subsequently print  the QR code and affixed to the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned  by the customer before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Food premises can operate at normal capacity rates;  3. Buffet food preparation is allowed on condition  food must be served by employees of restaurants, cafes or  food court;  4. Body temperature check must be done before entering the premises  food;  5. Owners of food premises must insure their employees  who handles and prepares food for constant wear  nose and mouth cover (face mask);  6. Unhealthy food premise employees are advised not to attend  working;  7. Ensure physical and social distancing including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Food premises are not allowed to increase the seating capacity  dine-in from normal capacity;  7.2 Food premises to provide special spaces or queues for  takeaway service;  7.3 Food premises to provide hand sanitiser;  7.4 Food premises are required to comply with internal guidelines  cleaning and sanitation of the premises.  8. Any food premise operators found not  comply with the aforementioned conditions, may be subject to action  law under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. Entrepreneurs of food premises are requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    ""1. Cinema owners or operators are required to obtain a QR code  Bruhealth specific to their premises and subsequently print a QR code  and affixed in the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned by  visitors before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Body temperature check must be done before entering the cinema;  4. Cinema owners or operators must ensure employees  them to always wear a nose and mouth mask (face mask);  5. Unhealthy cinema employees are advised not to attend  working;  6. Ensuring that the film will be shown will delay the screening time  after the end of a film screening to allow the cinema  clean the seats and surroundings of the cinema (fully sanitize);  7. Ensure physical and social incarceration including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Ensure the physical incarceration of cinema visitors to a minimum  one (1) seat. Customers who come in on a regular basis  groups are allowed to sit nearby;  7.2 Cinemas to display notice of the maximum amount of incoming capacity  at a time in an appropriate place;  7.3 Cinemas are not allowed to increase the seating capacity of  normal capacity; and  7.4 Cinema to provide hand sanitiser;  8. Any cinema owner or operator found to be non-compliant  the conditions mentioned earlier, may be subject to legal action  under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. The owner or operator of the cinema is requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time."" Cinema owners or operators are required to obtain a QR code  Bruhealth specific to their premises and subsequently print a QR code  and affixed in the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned by  visitors before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Limit the number of visitors allowed to enter at any one time to 80% of the total normal capacity of the space  sitting cinema concerned;  3. Body temperature check must be done before entering the cinema;  4. Cinema owners or operators must ensure employees  them to always wear a nose and mouth mask (face mask);  5. Unhealthy cinema employees are advised not to attend  working;  6. Ensuring that the film will be shown will delay the screening time  after the end of a film screening to allow the cinema  clean the seats and surroundings of the cinema (fully sanitize);  7. Ensure physical and social incarceration including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Ensure the physical incarceration of cinema visitors to a minimum  one (1) seat. Customers who come in on a regular basis  groups are allowed to sit nearby;  7.2 Cinemas to display notice of the maximum amount of incoming capacity  at a time in an appropriate place;  7.3 Cinemas are not allowed to increase the seating capacity of  normal capacity; and  7.4 Cinema to provide hand sanitiser;  8. Any cinema owner or operator found to be non-compliant  the conditions mentioned earlier, may be subject to legal action  under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. The owner or operator of the cinema is requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time."" No change. As mentioned on the entry on 09 Feb, the Ministry of Health reiterates its advisories given the then-impending Chinese New Year celebrations,  ""Those with large families are permitted to hold private events at banquet halls in hotels or restaurants provided that Mass Gathering guidelines are adhered to, including provision of hand sanitizers and conducting temperature checks at the premises. If the number of family members is huge, limit attendance to a maximum of 350 people.""    The Ministry continues to encourage safe distancing and other measures, including the limitation of events that are held to 2 hours.    See Ministry of Health's reiteration, archived at https://archive.vn/c7CpW  See also https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, the Ministry of Health's guidelines on mass gatherings, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/l0qb3n0bg8n31oz/BRN-20200924-Guidelines_MassGathering.pdf

No changes in policy.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 5 March, public transport is operating.    The Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications' previous guidelines from September 2020 remains in force:    ""Public Transport Operators are allowed to operate 100% vehicle seating capacity. However, Public Transport Operators as well passengers are still required to adhere to the prescribed guidelines  by the Ministry of Health.  1. Scan the Bruhealth QR code before entering Public transportation. Only Green and Yellow Codes are allowed to use Public Transport;  ii. Use of face mask when  in Public Transport vehicles and along the way;  iii. Avoid physical contact.  iv. Avoid chatting while inside vehicle.  v. Check body temperature before boarding vehicle.  vi. For bus passengers, must sit along the way.""      See Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications' Guidelines (in Malay), last updated 07 Sep 2020, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/xj97s2roah5u1la/BRN-20200907-PengemaskinianGarispanduan.pdf  See US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/fnAPh
