Moving the code from 2 to 4, as entry into Brunei remains severely limited for foreigners from all countries, including Singapore (which has a Reciprocal Green Lane' agreement with Brunei - however, visitors from Singapore are only allowed in on essential business trips and via the same Entry Travel Pass requirements imposed on all other foreigners) except those entering for essential purposes (see Entry Travel Pass requirements).    Per the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory,    ""The Bruneian government has imposed an entry ban on all foreign visitors (non-Brunei citizens/non-Brunei permanent residents), including transit passengers, from 24 March 2020 until further notice. Foreign visitors seeking to enter Brunei must receive prior approval from the Brunei Department of Immigration and National Registration.""    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 5 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.  Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.  Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.    Per the Ministry of Health,   From 20 March 2020, all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam  through any points of entry are required to undergo mandatory selfisolation for 14 days at a government-designated facility immediately  upon arrival to the country.  i) Self-isolation at private homes are not permitted.  ii) This include all visitors and foreign workers arriving in the  country.  iii) All foreign nationals including foreign workers arriving in the  country are required to bear fully the cost of mandatory selfisolation (including accommodation and meals) and laboratory  test for SARS-CoV-2 ($1000 per test).  iv) Foreign workers must submit special entry application for foreign  workers before arriving in Brunei Darussalam.     Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory, archived at https://archive.vn/pQ2MH  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/fnAPh  See the Ministry of Health's guidelines on travel, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/mpd9geybded3b1h/BRN-undated-Guidelines_Travel.pdf  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No change.    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 9 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.  Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.  Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards. No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 5 March,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200.  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/fnAPh

There has been no updates on vaccine rollout, or changes in vaccination policy since the Chinese shipment on 09 February.    For the press release by the Ministry of Health on the previous shipment donated by China (vaccine type: Sinopharm), https://archive.vn/hlNoU

Brunei has not started vaccinations, however, there has been new developments with regards to this:    As reported by the Borneo Bulletin on 6 March (https://archive.ph/ztw24), Brunei has outlined a vaccination strategy in three phases.    ""Brunei’s citizens and residents, including foreign nationals with a valid IC, will receive the COVID-19 vaccination for free. The vaccination process will be in place once the COVID-19 vaccine arrives in the country.    Details about the COVID-19 vaccination were revealed on the Brunei Darussalam Vaccination Strategy, Ministry of Health website. The vaccine distribution is divided into three phases.    Phase one is for frontliners, senior citizens aged 60 and above and students who will be studying overseas. Phase two is for the staff at childcare centres, adults at high risk and teachers, while phase three is for the public aged 18 and above.    Four locations have been identified for the inoculation of the vaccine. They are the Indoor Stadium in Brunei-Muara District, Pengiran Muda Mahkota Pengiran Muda Haji Al-Muhtadee Billah (PMMPMHAMB) Hospital in Tutong District, Suri Seri Begawan Hospital in Belait District and Pengiran Isteri Hajjah Mariam Hospital in Temburong District.    Bookings can be done through the BruHealth app by verifying the BruHealth account and clicking on the COVID-19 vaccination slot. Individuals must read the COVID-19 vaccination participation information statement and fill the questionnaires, according to the website.""    Additionally, the Bruneian Minister of Health Dato Seri Setia Dr Haji Mohd Isham bin Haji Jaafar announced on 6 March that the first COVAX vaccine (vaccine type unknown), will arrive in Brunei 'sometime this month [March]'.    See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the Vaccination Strategy, archived at https://archive.ph/ztw24  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the Minister of Health's comments on COVAX, archived at https://archive.ph/ZGx72  See the Ministry of Health's newly-released Vaccination Strategy Report, in Malay, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/7ltgnilgurhqtuv/BRN-20210306-MOH-StrategiVaksinasiNegaraBruneiDarussalam.pdf

Brunei has not started vaccinations, however, there have been 5 vaccine candidates that have been identified for Brunei, according to the Borneo Bulletin reported on 12 March (owned by the government of Brunei; reported in Xinhua)    ""According to local daily the Borneo Bulletin on Friday, the five candidates for Brunei people are vaccines from Pfizer BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca, China's Sinopharm, and Johnson and Johnson, respectively. The country's vaccination strategy will be implemented once the vaccines arrive in the country.""    As noted in previous notes, Brunei previously received its first shipment of Covid-19 vaccines (Sinopharm) from China on 09 February; and revealed its vaccination strategy on 06 March. As per the 06 March note, the country also expects to receive its first shipment of Covid-19 vaccines procured from the COVAX facility by the end of March.    See Xinhua's news report, archived at https://archive.ph/FLCv2

Vaccinations have still not started in Brunei.    There has been further progress in the logistics end for Brunei's vaccination. As per the Borneo Bulletin, reported on 23rd March, ""Four locations for the administration of the vaccine have been selected: Indoor Stadium in Brunei-Muara District; Pengiran Muda Mahkota Pengiran Muda Haji Al-Muhtadee Billah Hospital in Tutong District; Suri Seri Begawan Hospital in Belait District; and Pengiran Isteri Hajjah Mariam Hospital in Temburong District.""    See the Borneo Bulletin's report, archived at https://archive.vn/8jJAQ
Vaccinations have still not started in Brunei; there has been no new notable updates on its Vaccination Strategy.

In line with restaurants reopening, new rules were outlined and released on March 3. DPHSS Guidance Memo 2021-07 REV1 was updated to include the prohibition of salad bars, buffets, and self-service operations within Eating and Drinking Establishments. All other provisions remain unaffected at this time. COVID-19 vaccination clinics continue on Tuesday, March 23 to March 27, from 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. at the UOG Fieldhouse. These clinics will administer first doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and second doses of both the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.   PHASE 1a/1b/1c – CATEGORY: Healthcare workers; local and federal law enforcement personnel; School-based employees and Childcare Center employees; adults 40 years and older; Mayors’ Council of Guam (limited to mayors, vice mayors, and mayoral staff); funeral homes, mortuary, and cemetery staff; service providers contracted with the DPHSS Division of Senior Citizens providing direct patient or client care such as transportation for medical appointments, homebound meals, in-home services, caregiver services, case management, shelter care, adult daycare, and other direct services; and others who are due for dose two of the vaccine. Eligibility is subject to change. Upon arrival, individuals 60 years and older will be sent to the front of the line.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210324104012/https://guamrecovery.com/guams-vaccination-testing-updates/

Air crew and all other exempted people must wait for their COVID-19 test results at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) when entering the city via the airport from tomorrow. The government explained that the revisions in designated holding locations were made in view of the shortened waiting time for test results at HKIA. The change also aims to further mitigate the risk of exempted people coming into contact with other people during the holding period.    https://archive.ph/0S3tG

The Food Courts Subsidy Scheme was launched today and opened for applications to provide financial support to operators of eligible licensed food factories in operation, the Food & Environmental Hygiene Department announced. The scheme will provide a one-off subsidy ranging from $20,000 to $100,000 to licence holders of food factories according to the floor area of the premises as specified on the business operation licence.    https://archive.vn/3R1zM

The one-off free voluntary COVID-19 testing service provided to all construction site workers in Hong Kong will continue until March 31 and those who are eligible can book online from today.    https://archive.vn/6oys9

The existing arrangement for regular testing of staff of catering business premises and scheduled premises will continue, as it helps breaking the silent transmission chain in the community promptly.    https://archive.vn/38Za2#selection-737.5-737.177

A voluntary weekly testing scheme for certain airport staff target groups will commence on March 5, while the ongoing free testing services for all other airport staff will continue    https://archive.vn/W0BmU     The Government today said the supply of COVID-19 testing services is being further enhanced to cope with the increasing demand for testing in order to meet anti-epidemic goals and facilitate the public. The move was made having regard to the recent higher risk of transmission and infection in different premises or groups and the implementation of strengthened anti-epidemic measures for the resumption of economic and social activities.   At present, employees of scheduled premises and catering businesses, construction site workers, school staff, as well as local residents and staff subject to compulsory testing may receive free testing at community testing centres.  The appointment rate of the city's 19 community testing centres for the next seven days is only about 30%, with plenty of places available to meet the demand.  Moreover, about 20 mobile specimen collection stations are in service to provide free testing to the public.     https://archive.vn/lYWHm

A, B, C and additional priority groups (sinovac)    BioNTech vaccination suspended     The Government today announced that it immediately suspended COVID-19 vaccinations concerning BioNTech (Comirnaty) after deviations in the vial seal were found in one batch of the vaccine. It explained that it received written notification this morning from Fosun Industrial Co about the deviations that involve batch 210102. The Government noted that while BioNTech and Fosun Pharma have no reason to believe there is a risk to product safety, for the sake of prudence, vaccination of the batch concerned should be suspended pending an investigation.    https://archive.ph/lohJg

""JAKARTA, March 8 (Xinhua): Indonesia has extended the micro-scale community activities restriction policy in Java and Bali until March 22 while expanding it to three provinces, a senior official said on Monday.    ""The imposition of the restriction for the past two weeks succeeded in reducing the number of active Covid-19 cases and new cases,"" said Chairman of the Committee for Handling Covid-19 and National Economic Recovery Airlangga Hartarto.    East Kalimantan, South Sulawesi and North Sumatra provinces have begun to apply the micro-scale community activities restriction policy as the cases of Covid-19 there have increased significantly.    During the micro-scale restriction implementation, the number of employees working in the office is limited to 50 percent, while the rest work from home. Restaurants are only allowed to accept diners to eat at a maximum of 50 per cent, and school activities are carried out online."" - March 8, 2021 https://archive.vn/WsDKA#selection-2681.83-2695.281

Prime minister Suga on Thursday (March 18th) announced that the monthslong emergency measures for Tokyo, Kanagawa, Chiba and Saitama would end at midnight Sunday.  https://archive.ph/IIc4o    However, “the end of the state of emergency in Tokyo and three neighbouring prefectures on Sunday will not be quite as liberating as it sounds – the ban on boozing beneath the blossoms is only one of several restrictions that will remain. No policy changes.    National guidelines continue to be events are allowed, but with a restriction to 5000 people.    (Maximum number of people / accommodation rate)  [Indoor] 5000 people or less and 50% or less of the capacity  [Outdoor] 5000 people or less and a sufficient distance between people (2m as much as possible)  https://archive.ph/i45NU    For example, this weekend, the next bi-monthly grand Sumo tournament will start, with audience and under social distancing and hygiene restrictions.   https://archive.ph/cdFA2  https://archive.ph/HvvVQ    The traditional cherry blossom viewing events at this time of year that typically draw large crowds are discouraged.  https://archive.ph/X69fv#selection-513.0-529.8

The government continues to restrict large gatherings.  [Indoor] 5000 people or less and 50% or less of the capacity  [Outdoor] 5000 people or less and a sufficient distance between people (2m as much as possible)  https://archive.ph/AN7QP    Some gatherings are cancelled altogether. For example, the usual cherry blossom viewing parties at this time of the year are prohibited in Tokyo.  “In Tokyo parks that would normally be filled with picnicking families, signs warn that flower-viewing parties are forbidden. Popular spots have been roped off and festivals cancelled or scaled down. Illuminations will not be switched on and security guards will be on the lookout for anyone grabbing a furtive beer and bento. Instead, blossom viewing will be restricted to masked strolls in designated areas.”  https://archive.ph/63GkT    This applies in other prefectures as well: local governments are livestreaming trees, which are expected to reach full bloom on Tuesday, and posting archived images of the petals in their prime.  https://archive.ph/63GkT#selection-1813.47-1813.198    However, while in Tokyo the number of spectators continues to be restricted to 5000 (see above), the maximum number of spectators allowed at the popular annual High School Baseball Championship (Koshien, near Kobe) is 10,000.   https://archive.ph/IOW8K

Cherry blossom viewing parties continue to be discouraged, although there is no complete ban on cherry blossom viewing: “In a video address on Monday, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike stopped short of telling people not to go out to enjoy the flowers but asked that they keep hanami activities to ""just looking"".”    At the same time, “Many parks in the capital region are prohibiting hanami (cherry blossom viewing), with some erecting temporary fences to keep people from gathering near the trees. “  https://archive.ph/VnEhW    The restrictions on the number of attendees at events appears to have been increased to 10,000.  “Five professional baseball teams based in one metropolitan area and three prefectures have been able to increase the number of spectators from 5,000 to 10,000 from the start of the season on the 26th of this month after the state of emergency was lifted on the 21st. It was decided to raise it to.”  https://archive.ph/d5dve    The Tokyo government defines the maximum number of people as follows:  [Maximum number of people] 5,000 people or 50% or less of capacity (=10,000 people), whichever is larger  https://archive.ph/17E4z

Tests continue only for people with symptoms, via referral by a medical doctor.  Data published on the Health Ministry’s website about No. of PCR tests conducted  shows that the number of tests has decreased since a peak in early January, which correlates with the numbers of infections. It also shows that the majority of tests have been done via private test companies, rather than public health centres or medical institutions.   https://archive.ph/QTfTd    These tests at private companies seem to be government-funded. · Medical insurance will be applied to PCR tests (from March 6th). As a result, medical institutions will be able to make direct requests to private testing institutions without going through a health center, and the testing capabilities of private testing companies will be further utilized.  https://archive.ph/XRoqC

No policy changes.    The period of inoculation is scheduled from February 17, 3rd year of Reiwa (2021) to the end of February 4th year of Reiwa (2022(. Initially, vaccinations will be given to medical staff. After that, it is expected that vaccination will proceed in the order of elderly people and those with underlying diseases. Inoculation to the elderly is expected to start on April 12 in some municipalities. Initially, the number of municipalities to be vaccinated and the number of people to be vaccinated are limited, and the number will be gradually expanded.    https://archive.vn/k02nl

A  Pfizer    No policy changes. Only medical workers being vaccinated. The elderly will start to be vaccinated from April 12th.   https://archive.ph/tqd6v  Pfizer continues to be the only vaccine being used.  https://archive.ph/Pj7k4    To add some color, there appears to be a perception of a slow vaccine rollout: “The first drop of vaccines for Tokyo’s 14 million has only just begun, and until we’re done, we have to fight with our bare hands,” Koike said, in reference to the government’s slow rollout of Covid jabs.”  https://archive.ph/63GkT#selection-1725.0-1729.15

A - Medical workers  Pfizer  No policy changes.  https://archive.ph/T33pO    Japan is in the midst of inoculating about 4.8 million health care workers and plans to expand the vaccine rollout to the rest of the population, starting off with people aged 65 or older, a group of about 36 million, from April 12.  https://archive.ph/jrsRt    As a side note, there is increased activity to develop vaccines in Japan. Daiichi has started testing an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine,  which however will likely take until late this year or early next year to get approved.   The Daiichi trial is part of a flurry of studies of Japanese COVID-19 vaccines. Shionogi became the second company to trial a Japan-originated COVID-19 vaccine late last year, and KM Biologics disclosed the initiation of its study on the same day as Daiichi.   These homegrown vaccines will likely play a role in combatting future variants of the virus.  https://archive.ph/N6q8k    Public perception continues to be that the vaccine rollout is slow.  https://archive.ph/ujhQo

""All travel to and from Preah Sihanouk Province has been suspended until further notice, according to a statement released by the Preah Sihanouk provincial administration on March 4.  Local police have established checkpoints on Highway 3 and at the junction between Highway 4 and Highway 48 in response to this measure.  American citizens are advised to avoid travel to Preah Sihanouk Province. The provincial governments of Pailin, Kep, and Siem Reap have also announced certain restrictions or requirements for travelers in and out of their respective provinces. Travel restrictions have also been reported for Takeo and Tbong Khmum provinces, as well as for certain communes in Prey Veng province.""    ""Is a curfew in place? Following the Declaration of State of Emergency in March 2020 a temporary and partial lockdown was announced which affected schools and those under 18 years of age.  The school closure began on 30th March 2020 and UNSDG indicates that they reopened on 20th April.  No evidence for changed school practices has been found and so code since 20th April 2020 has been ""0"" (no measures)    http://archive.today/2021.02.15-164719/https://unsdg.un.org/un-in-action/kiribati

The declaration of a State of Emergency on 26th March 2020 referred to temporary restrictive measures for schools and young people aged 18 and under.  No reference to closure of businesses has been found and so C2 has been coded ""0"" (no measures) since 1st January 2020.

The initial declaration of a State of Emergency on 26th March 2020 made no reference to public events and gatherings.  Restrictive measures referred to only involved schools and young people aged 18 and under which was temporary.  There have been no confirmed cases of Covid-19 in Kiribati.  C3 has been coded ""0"" (no measures) from 1st January 2020 to date.    http://archive.today/2021.01.17-134153/https://www.micttd.gov.ki/news/kiribati-declares-state-public-emergency-and-partial-lock-down-response-corona-virus-pandemic

The initial declaration of a State of Emergency on 26th March 2020 made no reference to public events and gatherings.  Restrictive measures referred to only involved schools and young people aged 18 and under which was temporary.  There have been no confirmed cases of Covid-19 in Kiribati.  C3 has been coded ""0"" (no measures) from 1st January 2020 to date.    http://archive.today/2021.01.17-134153/https://www.micttd.gov.ki/news/kiribati-declares-state-public-emergency-and-partial-lock-down-response-corona-virus-pandemic

Following the Declaration of State of Emergency in March 2020 a temporary and partial lockdown was announced which affected schools and included stay at home requirements for those under 18 years of age.  The school closure began on 30th March 2020 and UNSDG indicates that they reopened on 20th April.  Stay at home requirements for those under 18 years of age were assumed to have ceased at this time and so code has been ""0"" (no measures) since 20th April 2020.    http://archive.today/2021.01.17-134153/https://www.micttd.gov.ki/news/kiribati-declares-state-public-emergency-and-partial-lock-down-response-corona-virus-pandemic    http://archive.today/2021.02.15-164719/https://unsdg.un.org/un-in-action/kiribati

As noted on 22nd February, the border closure was due to be reviewed at end February, however no updates have been found on:  a) Office of Te Beretitenti (Office of the President) https://www.president.gov.ki/    b) Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.mfa.gov.ki/   c) Ministry of Health and medical Services: https://www.mhms.gov.ki/important-notices.html    The Office of Te Beretenti continues to include a note: ""Attention: Our Boarder is to remain closed until further notice.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.15-162133/https://www.president.gov.ki/

Radio New Zealand article:    ""Kiribati extends border closures  The Kiribati Government has officially extended its Covid-19 border closure until the end of June.    The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said special approvals would still be available for humanitarian flights and for medevacs.    The Government's Repatriation Taskforce was continuing facilitate repatriation exercises to bring back all i-Kiribati stranded overseas.    The Taskforce is also co-ordinating efforts to try and get Kiribati students to Fiji so they can commence their tertiary level studies.    A 14 quarantine at the government facility on South Tarawa remains mandatory.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.22-153439/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/438464/in-brief-news-from-around-the-pacific-for-16-march

As noted on 22nd March, borders remain closed and the official site of the Office of Te Beretenti continues to display message confirming this    http://archive.today/2021.03.29-165842/https://www.president.gov.ki/

As previously noted on 31st July 2020, the Public Health Infectious Disease Regulation does refer to measures applied to suspected and confirmed cases of Covid-19, there are no clear references to contact tracing. A month-long social media campaign was launched to disseminate information on ways to stay protected and keep others safe too. The online reach through social media grew, giving opportunities for children themselves to encourage learning, for example, through 'read aloud' activities but also key messages on returning to schools. So far, the campaign reached 4.6 million people via UNICEF online platforms, including 1.2 million views of the videos since its launch on 22 April 2020.  Similarly, a Whatsapp group was set up to send daily tailored messages to teachers across the country..  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104193722/https://www.unicef.org/laos/stories/going-back-school-new-normal-setting

Myanmar has received its free first batch of Covishield, AstraZeneca’s vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India. More than 110000 Healthcare workers and volunteers will be vaccinated as part of the initial phase.   This will be followed by the government official and the elderly over the age of 65.   About 20 percent of the 54.4 million population in Myanmar will be given vaccines under the global Covax affordable medicines program and the Global Alliance for Vaccine and Immunisation.The first batch of COVID-19 vaccine under the World Health Organization’s Covax program will arrive in late February, according to the health ministry.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308203126/https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/myanmar-health-ministry-continue-vaccinations-despite-coup.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308203526/https://www.reuters.com/article/myanmar-politics-india-idUSKBN2A41VE

'Director of the Vaccination Department of the National Center for Communicable Diseases reported that since February 23, when the vaccination campaign kicked off in Mongolia, a total of around 13,200 people have received the first dose of AztraZeneca vaccine against coronavirus until today, March 4, Montsame reports.  Among them, 9500 people are healthcare personnel, including members of the teams administering COVID-19 vaccine, and 2,600 people are the first responders against CVOID-19, such as police, emergency management and professional inspection officials.  ...  According to the Ministry of Health, people over 50s, people with disabilities, individuals with underlying medical conditions, such as those with cardiovascular diseases, diabetes and cancer, groups of individuals of ready reserve mobilization for COVID-19 vaccination and response measures, employees of strategically-important sectors, such as border employees and coal-hauling truck drivers and employees of all-levels of educational organizations are next in line to receive coronavirus vaccines.'    https://archive.ph/R3eIP

As of 22 March, '[a] total of 223,444 people received first dose of vaccine so far nationwide, including 218,400 people in Ulaanbaatar and 5,044 people in Umnugobi aimag, since the vaccination campaign launched on February 23, Montsame reports.  According to the WHO recommendations, 98 percent of healthcare workers and 99 percent of personnel of other organizations that are working in the frontline to fight the COVID-19 have been inoculated. In Ulaanbaatar, about 185,000 people aged 50-64 are currently eligible for the first dose, of whom 19.5 percent have been inoculated. In addition, people over the age of 65 and those who had the transplants started receiving the first dose on March 22.'    https://archive.vn/De3Yz

28 February 2021  Auckland moves to Alert Level 3 at 6am. The rest of New Zealand move to Alert Level 2.  ""At Alert Level 3, children and young people should learn from home.    Any child who can’t be supervised at home by an appropriate person can attend their service or school.     A wide range of businesses and services can operate at Alert Level 3, which means that parents and caregivers may be required to go to work, rather than work from or stay at home. Services and schools must be open for children in these situations to attend.    Play centres and playgroups will be closed.    Home-based early learning services can open with a maximum number of 4 licensed children, including the educators’ own children, provided they meet public health requirements.    ""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315225135/https://covid19.govt.nz/everyday-life/parents-caregivers-and-whanau/education/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315224754/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/history-of-the-covid-19-alert-system/

""On 10 February, the Commission of Higher Education and the Department of Health approved guidelines for the gradual reopening of colleges and universities for limited face-to-face classes in areas under general community quarantine (GCQ) and modified general community quarantine (MGCQ).    General Community Quarantine (GCQ) through March 31, 2021:  Luzon?– National Capital Region, Batangas, Baguio City, Apayao, Kalinga, and Mountain Province in the Cordillera Administrative Region.   Visayas?–Tacloban City; and Mindanao – Davao City, Iligan City, and Lanao Del Sur.  All other areas are under?Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309014800/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Manila City (six barangays) and Quezon City (specific areas) have been placed under lockdown. Minors are not allowed to go outside their residences, only individuals aged 18-65 years old are allowed to go outside their residences amid the alarming rising number of COVID-19 cases in Metro Manila starting March 17, 2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000507/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as stringent limitations on movement. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ) as transition period between ECQ and General Community Quarantine (GCQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. Effective until April 30, 2021 Luzon, the entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR); Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya are placed under MECQ. All other areas are placed under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ) until end of April 2021. Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’. Under ECQ ‘face-to-face classes at all levels shall be suspended.’ https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

General Community Quarantine (GCQ) through March 31, 2021:  Luzon?– National Capital Region, Batangas, Baguio City, Apayao, Kalinga, and Mountain Province in the Cordillera Administrative Region.   Visayas?–Tacloban City; and Mindanao – Davao City, Iligan City, and Lanao Del Sur.  All other areas are under?Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309014800/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      Food establishments and gyms continue to be closed under GCQ definitions    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208030031/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/436671/philippines-authorities-extend-community-quarantine-rules-through-feb-28-lifts-travel-ban-from-some-locations-starting-feb-1-update-58""

Manila City – Six barangays are under lockdown starting at 12:01 a.m. March 17 until 11:59 p.m. on March 20. Exemptions include: healthcare workers, policy and military personnel, government employees, essential service workers (pharmacies, drug stores and death care establishments), barangay officials, media practitioners accredited by Presidential Communications Operations Office, and Inter-Agency Task Force.  Quezon City – Specific areas (not entire barangays or villages) have been placed under a special concern lockdown due to a sudden surge of COVID-19 cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000507/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318021308/https://manila.gov.ph/2021/03/updates-manila-city-mayor-francisco-isko-moreno-domagoso-places-six-barangays-under-lockdown-starting-1201-am-on-march-17-until-1159-pm-on-march-20/

Effective March 22 to April 4 2021, additional restrictions will be placed on the specified Subject Area of Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region.  All mass gatherings including religious gatherings are prohibited.  Holdings of weddings, baptisms, and funeral services are limited to 10 persons.  Private sector is enjoined to adopt alternative working arrangements i.e. 30% to 50% operational or on-site capacity. Restaurants and cafes limited to delivery, take-out, and outdoor dining only. Temporary suspension of driving schools, cinemas, game arcades, libraries, archives, museums and cultural centres.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323024044/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/memorandum-from-the-executive-secretary-additional-measures-to-address-the-rising-cases-of-covid-19-in-the-country/

Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as the strictest of lockdown measures. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. Effective until April 30, 2021 Luzon, the entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR); Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya are placed under General Community Quarantine (MGCQ). All other areas are placed under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ) until end of April 2021.  Exemptions of the ECQ include: Public and private hospitals; health emergency and frontline services; manufacturers of medical supplies; agricultural industries; logistics service providers; construction projects; hygiene products manufacturing; essential retail trade; food preparation establishments; public and private financial service providers. https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

In areas under General Community Quarantine, Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine, or Enhanced Community Quarantine, mass gatherings such as but not limited to, movie screenings, concerts, sporting events, and other entertainment activities, community assemblies, and non-essential work gatherings are prohibited.    In areas under Modified General Community Quarantine, mass gatherings such as but not limited to, movie screenings, concerts, sporting events, and other entertainment activities, religious services, and work conferences are allowed provided that participants are limited to 50% of the seating or venue capacity. All other areas, including cities of Santiago and Ormoc, are under Modified General Community quarantine (MGCQ).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Effective March 22 to April 4 2021, additional restrictions will be placed on the specified Subject Area of Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region.  All mass gatherings including religious gatherings are prohibited.  Holdings of weddings, baptisms, and funeral services are limited to 10 persons.  Private sector is enjoined to adopt alternative working arrangements i.e. 30% to 50% operational or on-site capacity. Restaurants and cafes limited to delivery, take-out, and outdoor dining only. Temporary suspension of driving schools, cinemas, game arcades, libraries, archives, museums and cultural centres.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323024044/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/memorandum-from-the-executive-secretary-additional-measures-to-address-the-rising-cases-of-covid-19-in-the-country/

Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as the strictest of lockdown measures. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. In all areas, strict home quarantine shall be observed in all households, and the movement of all residents shall still be limited to accessing essential goods and services, and for work in permitted offices or establishments or such specified activities.    Any person below 15 years old, those who are over 65 years old, those with immunodeficiency, comorbidity, or other health risks, and pregnant women, including any person who resides with the aforementioned, shall be required to remain in their residences at all times, except when indispensable under the circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services, or for work in industries and offices or such other activities permitted in this section.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf

Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as the strictest of lockdown measures. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. Effective until April 30, 2021 Luzon, the entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR); Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya are placed under General Community Quarantine (MGCQ). All other areas are placed under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ) until end of April 2021. Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

The movement of the following authorized persons outside their residences (APOR)  within and across areas placed under any form of community quarantine shall be  permitted:  Health and emergency frontline services personnel  Government officials and government frontline personnel  Duly-authorized humanitarian assistance actors (HAAs)  Persons traveling for medical or humanitarian reasons  Persons going to the airport for travel abroad  Anyone crossing zones for work or business permitted in the zone of destination, and going back home.    The following persons shall also be considered as APOR:  Returning or repatriated OFWs and other Overseas Filipinos (OFs) returning to their places of residence  Other persons transported through the efforts of the national government upon observance of the necessary quarantine protocols and with the concurrence of the receiving LGUs.    The Philippine National Police shall be authorized to promulgate and regularly update the list of APORs.    Authorized shuttle services shall be allowed to travel within and across areas placed under any form of community quarantine, with priority given to persons rendering health and emergency frontline services.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf

On 28 February, the 600,000 doses of Sinovac-made vaccines finally arrived in Manila on Sunday as part of China's commitment to supporting the Philippines' vaccination rollout.    The Chinese military plane carrying the donated vials called CoronaVac landed at the Villamor Airbase in Pasay City past 4 p.m. and was welcomed by several Cabinet members.    President Rodrigo Duterte also witnessed the historic event and inspected the crates containing the vials, the first-ever to arrive in the Philippines, during its ceremonial turnover to the Philippine government.    In his speech, Duterte thanked the Chinese government for the vaccine donation, confident that more batches of vaccines will be available at the earliest possible opportunity.    “I convey my sincere gratitude to the Chinese people and the government of China for this gesture of friendship and solidarity – the hallmark of Philippines-China partnership,” he said.    Duterte also reiterated his statement that Covid-19 vaccines should be treated as a global public good and made available to all, rich and poor alike    “No nation – no people - should be left to suffer the ravages of this pandemic for whatever reason,"" he said.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061604/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1132107

The measures in the new normal  are as follows:    Clean your hands often. Wash with soap and water or use an alcohol based sanitizer;  Keep a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters between yourself and others;  Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth;  Greet others with a smile, a nod or a simple hello-no handshakes, no fist bumps and no high fives;  Cough and sneeze in your bent elbow and not your hands;  Limit social gathering and time spent in crowded places;  Wear a face mask or face covering in all public places to protect yourself and others; and  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.  https://archive.vn/dMa7n

Authorities have tightened restrictions across Morobe Province through 1200 March 19 due to rising COVID-19 activity in Lae, Huon Gulf, and Nawae districts. Officials have banned gatherings of more than 50 people. Retail stores and markets can continue to operate, but owners must closely enforce social distancing and hygiene edicts. Restaurants must limit capacity to 50 percent. High-risk businesses, such as gambling houses, bars, and nightclubs, have closed. Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain government-paid or government-subsidized testing services at Port Moresby General Hospital and the Taurama Aquatic Center drive-through testing site operated by St. John Ambulance service. Testing services outside of Port Moresby may be obtained by visiting a provincial hospital or by calling 1800 200 and asking for more information.  Non-symptomatic persons and persons who need testing services in connection with travel may obtain such services through approved swabbing centers and private medical facilities, including:  St John Ambulance  2K Medical Clinic  Pacific International Hospital  Aspen Medical  Sky Medical Services  Testing conducted through private medical facilities may cost as much as 250 USD.  Though electronic test results from such facilities are generally available within 24-48 hours, U.S. citizens who need tests in connection with travel are advised to request clear estimates of the turn-around and delivery methods for test results and to pay for expedited processing if needed.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDC’s requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID test,  Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID testing capacity. To submit information in support of an exemption   http://web.archive.org/web/20210308010332/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

People must wear face coverings at all indoor locations, including offices and government agencies, public transport, and airplanes, nationwide, except if under 12 years old or while eating. The government is requiring businesses and public transport operators to deny entry to people without face coverings. All companies with indoor operations must provide workers with face coverings and ensure their use.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315135045/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/453736/papua-new-guinea-authorities-issue-additional-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-march-11-update-27

The code of 1G continues to be valid and signifies that the educational arrangements are significantly different to the situation prior to the Covid-19 pandemic.  The ""safe management measures"" from the Ministry of Education FAQ page are detailed below:    ""With school reopening in 2021, what are the safe management measures put in place in schools?""    ""Safe management measures in schools will continue to include the following:    Screening    Twice-daily temperature-taking and visual screening for all students and staff.  Students and staff who are unwell, or who have household members on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice or have adult household members with flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough, are required to stay away from school.  It is not mandatory for students to have their TraceTogether tokens when school reopens. The tokens will only be required in schools after nationwide distribution is completed.    Hygiene    Frequent cleaning of high-touch surfaces and disinfection of the premises to be done daily.  Students will continue to practise frequent hand-washing throughout the school day and wipe down of tables and shared equipment after use.    Safe Distancing    Fixed group seating of up to eight from the same class will be allowed.  CCAs and external learning journeys of up to 50 people conducted in a fixed group with exclusive use of venues (if possible) are allowed.  Curricular, co-curricular and enrichment activities with fixed intermingling across schools are allowed.  Staggered arrival, dismissal and recess timings to reduce congestion.""        Will all CCAs and school activities be resumed? [UPDATED, 18 Feb, 6:45pm]  Most CCAs and school activities are allowed to resume while activities that involve the following will remain suspended:    Trips to view external performances due to higher risk of intermingling with other schools and the public;  Activities with high level of body contact such as Taekwondo sparring, Rugby scrum and tackle;  Overnight camps.  Schools will continue to safeguard our students' well-being during CCAs and school activities, by implementing the necessary safe management measures (SMMs). This includes minimising prolonged inter-mingling between students and members of the public for activities held at external venues, such as Learning Journeys.    From SG Ministry of Education FAQs.  (Cannot be archived as the page consists of drop down items.  The page link is here:  https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection).

Previous entry on 12th February as follows:    The code 2G is given to reflect that nightclubs and karaoke bars remain closed (with 3 exceptions (see note on 5th February)).  As noted in previous entry on 19th January, a plan to pilot the re-opening of nightclubs and karaoke bars was postponed till further notice in response to a rise in numbers of Covid19 cases.  As noted on 5th February, this remains the case, although 3 bars which were opened during the pilot phase (at Orchard Plaza, Cuppage Plaza and Boat Quay) have been allowed to stay open.    (Link to earlier article from Straits Times:  http://archive.today/2021.02.12-145755/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/pilot-plans-to-reopen-nightclubs-and-karaoke-joints-put-on-hold-mti-mha)

National Environment Agency advisory:    ""Qing Ming festival takes place on 4 April 2021, with the visiting period expected to last from 20 March to 18 April 2021. In view of the continued COVID-19 situation and strict safe distancing measures, the National Environment Agency (NEA) has put in place stricter crowd control measures to limit crowds, and urges members of the public to exercise socially responsible behaviour to protect our well-being and that of our families and relatives. Those feeling unwell or are sick should stay at home, see a doctor, and avoid visiting. As crowds are expected at Choa Chu Kang Cemetery and government-managed columbaria during the Qing Ming period, visitors are requested to:    Minimise the family size visiting to two pax per household, with not more than eight pax per group;  Not bring elderly family members and young children;  Not eat and drink, or prolong their stay at the facilities;  Avoid crowding around the prayer and joss paper burning areas at the columbaria;  Keep a safe distance of at least 1 metre from other visitors, and wear a mask at all times; and  Carpool and register their vehicles if they intend to drive and park at Mandai Columbarium on peak days.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.08-190310/https://www.nea.gov.sg/media/news/advisories/index/public-advisory-on-safe-distancing-measures-at-government-cemetery-and-columbaria-for-qing-ming-festival

Significant changes now in place depending on whether venue carries out pre-event testing.      - e.g. ""Live performances. Live performances at designated venues will be allowed to have up to 750 attendees if they implement pre-event testing, or to have up to 250 attendees if they do not implement pre-event testing. The National Arts Council will release updated guidelines on audience management at live performances subsequently.""  - Similar rules apply to pilot Sports events and to business events.  In the case of business events the announcement refers to the division of the participants into zones of no more than 50 persons.  - ""15.      From 24 April 2021, individuals who have completed the full vaccination regimen and have had time to develop sufficient protection (i.e. two weeks after the second dose of the Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccination) can gain entry to events that implement pre-event testing without the need to undergo pre-event testing. MOH will be releasing further information and tools to support the implementation of pre-event testing, which will be made available at https://go.gov.sg/pet when ready.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.26-165024/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expansion-of-vaccination-programme-further-easing-of-community-measures

""Prohibition on social gatherings  6.—(1)  Subject to paragraph (1A), an individual must not gather with any other individual, outside of the individual’s ordinary place of residence for a purpose that is not performing work as, for or with a permitted enterprise and outside of a place of residence to which regulation 4(4) applies, except in a cohort —  (a)	that is a solemnization special cohort or a cohort in regulation 7A(2A)(b)(ii), where the purpose of gathering is the solemnization of a marriage;  (b)	that is a wedding special cohort or a cohort in regulation 8(1)(c)(ii), where the purpose of gathering is a wedding; or  (c)	in any other case, that consists of —  (i)	individuals all of whom are from the same household; or  (ii)	not more than 8 individuals.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.12-190511/https://sso.agc.gov.sg/SL/COVID19TMA2020-S254-2020?DocDate=20201031%2523pr3A-%23pr6-

10.      Social and recreational gatherings, such as team bonding events organised by the employer, will be allowed but must be limited to a total size of no more than 8 persons.     http://archive.today/2021.03.26-165024/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expansion-of-vaccination-programme-further-easing-of-community-measures

Policy update from Ministry of Health    Workplace restrictions:    ""8.      We will shift from working-from-home as a default to a more flexible and hybrid way of working. Employers are encouraged to continue with work-from-home arrangements, but more employees will be allowed to return to the workplace to better support work and business operations. In particular up to 75% of the employees (who are presently able to work from home) can now be at the workplace at any one time, up from the current 50%. The current cap on the time an employee spends at the workplace will also be lifted.""    ""9.      Employers should continue to stagger start times and implement flexible working hours where possible. These measures help to lower transmission risks by reducing interactions at the workplace and reducing crowding at common spaces at or near the workplace and in public places, including public transport. Split team arrangements are no longer mandatory, although companies may continue to adopt such arrangements for business continuity purposes if they so choose. Restrictions against cross-deployment across workplaces remain in place""    http://archive.today/2021.03.26-165024/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expansion-of-vaccination-programme-further-easing-of-community-measures    Coding note: although there are clearly significant lifting of restrictions regarding workplaces with up to 75% of the workforce being allowed to return to the workplace and no limit on the time spent in the workplace, there continues to be a recommendation that ""Employers are encouraged to continue with work-from-home arrangements"".  Consequently the coding has been left unchanged at ""1"" (Recommend staying at home) rather than ""0"" (No measures)

The SG government approach to border controls is summarised in the link below.    In broad terms,  the guidelines separate arrivals into specific groups: citizens, permanent residents, families of citizens and permanent residents, long term pass holders, short term visitors and work pass holders.      Short term visitors are allowed to enter Singapore for ""any purpose of travel"" under the Air Travel Pass Scheme if they are travelling from Australia, Brunei Darussalam,  Mainland China, New Zealand and Taiwan.  As noted on 9th February, this arrangement has been suspended for Vietnam.    Short term visitors are also permitted to enter Singapore under the Green Lanes Scheme if the purpose of the visit is ""Business and Official Travel"" AND if they are travelling from Brunei Darussalam, Germany, Indonesia, Japan, Mainland China, Malaysia and the Republic of Korea.    By implication, this means that short term visitors are not allowed into Singapore for ""Any Purpose of Travel"" if their departure point is not listed.  Thus the code for C8 continues to be a ""3"" - ban arrivals from some regions.    http://archive.today/2021.02.26-140807/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/arriving/overview

Summary of travel restrictions in note on 8th March continues to be in place.    In addition, Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung discusses possibility of opening up travel corridors for passengers who have been vaccinated from countries with ""low to moderate infection rates"" in the second half of 2021.  An IATA Travel Pass scheme is being piloted on flights from London to Singapore    http://archive.today/2021.03.12-180929/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/travel-corridors-for-vaccinated-passengers-could-open-in-the-second-half-of-2021-ong-ye

""The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) started the first phase of the vaccination exercise for 1,050 Home Team officers involved in frontline healthcare operations[1] on 11 January this year. MHA has since also commenced vaccination for our Home Team officers who are performing frontline enforcement and essential services duties. Overall, 83% of medically eligible officers have chosen to receive the vaccination.       The Commissioners and Heads of Department of the Singapore Civil Defence Force, Singapore Police Force, Immigration & Checkpoints Authority, Singapore Prison Service, Central Narcotics Bureau and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) have also received their vaccination, together with their officers. ""    http://archive.today/2021.03.01-170003/https://www.mha.gov.sg/newsroom/press-release/news/more-than-26-000-home-team-frontliners-have-received-the-covid-19-vaccination

Groups ""A,C:""    Article below from MOH provides overview of vaccine prioritisation.  Notes vaccination of elderly groups (>70 years old) began on 22nd February and will extend to those over 60 years old later this month.  The second group consists of health workers and those in critical roles (e.g. security agencies and those responsible for utilities).  Other groups mentioned are those where there is higher risk of transmission (e.g. those who work in markets and in educational establishments.  Migrant workers living in dormitories are also mentioned with a plan to vaccinate 10,000 who have ""never been infected by Covid 19 and are living in the five largest dormitories"".  Finally it refers to ""selected cargo drivers and accompanying personnel who enter Singapore from Malaysia on a regular basis"".      The article ends: ""We will continue to systematically extend the vaccination to other segments from April onwards. All Singaporeans and long-term residents in Singapore will have the chance to be vaccinated. ""    Coding note: Group C (Elderly Groups) and Group A (Key workers) are clearly referred to in the policy.  The reference to ""Higher Risk Groups"" in this article does not appear to refer to Group B (Clinically Vulnerable Groups), but rather to individuals who are at higher risk of exposure to Covid-19 and the article makes no clear reference to Group B.    http://archive.today/2021.03.08-181420/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/covid-19-vaccination-brought-forward-for-all-seniors-extended-to-essential-services-personnel-and-higher-risk-groups

Straits Times article with useful summary of the timeline and groups for vaccination strategy:    8th Jan: healthcare workers  11th jan: Home Team Officers  13th Jan: Singapore Airlines staff  14th Jan: Armed Forces  18th Jan: frontline workers in aviation and maritime sectors  27th Jan: pilot for seniors aged >70  22nd Feb: roll out of vaccines for all seniors aged > 70  23rd Feb: taxi and private hire drivers    Over the coming weeks, vaccination policy will be extended to:  Postal staff  Delivery staff  Reporters  Critical bank operation staff  Hawker stall holders and assistants  Teachers / staff in schools  Migrant workers in dormitories  Cargo drivers coming from Malaysia    As noted on 8th March, although the policy is expanding, no specific mention is made of ""group B ""Clinically vulnerable groups"".  It is coded as ""2"" (Two groups) referring to groups A and C taking a wide definition of ""Keyworkers"" although it is relevant to note that the expansion of the policy mentions those at high risk of coming into contact/spreading the virus rather than being Keyworkers per se.    http://archive.today/2021.03.12-174255/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/singapores-covid-19-vaccination-drive-brought-forward-for-all-seniors-extended-to

Groups: A,C: (also see previous notes and note below suggesting that vaccine rollout is extending beyond groups A and C.  Code of ""3"" is not warranted as no reference has been found to Group B, and code ""4"" is also not applicable as the vaccine is not ""broadly available"".  Hence decision to leave code as ""2"")    Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer (see note below)    MOH Press Release: highlights the increase in numbers of vaccine centres and the vaccines currently in use:    ""Four of the seven upcoming vaccination centres will administer the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine. These four vaccination centres are at Hong Kah North Community Club, Marsiling Community Club, Punggol 21 Community Club and Radin Mas Community Club. The other vaccination centres, polyclinics and selected PHPCs will continue to offer the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine. As more supplies of the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine arrive, more vaccination centres will offer the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.22-144711/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/more-vaccination-centres-nationwide-with-the-roll-out-of-the-moderna-vaccine    Straits Times Article: ""Singapore residents under 'exceptional circumstances' can apply for early Covid-19 vaccination""    http://archive.today/2021.03.22-150521/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/those-who-need-to-travel-overseas-for-urgent-work-study-or-medical-reasons-can-apply-for

Groups: A,C + others  Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer    Policy update from Ministry of Health    Key points:  a) Vaccine roll out  - As of 23 March 1.1 million doses of vaccine have been administered and almost 800,000 citizens have received at least one dose.  - Vaccination of adults over 70 began on 22nd February  - Vaccination of adults 60 and over was initiated in mid march  - Adults aged 45-59 can now register for vaccination    Coding note: the vaccination policy has now widened out to include those aged 45 and over but is not widely available to those under 45 years of age.  No reference is made to clinically vulnerable groups.  The code is therefore unchanged at ""2"".    http://archive.today/2021.03.26-165024/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expansion-of-vaccination-programme-further-easing-of-community-measures

National Environment Agency advisory:    ""Qing Ming festival takes place on 4 April 2021, with the visiting period expected to last from 20 March to 18 April 2021. In view of the continued COVID-19 situation and strict safe distancing measures, the National Environment Agency (NEA) has put in place stricter crowd control measures to limit crowds, and urges members of the public to exercise socially responsible behaviour to protect our well-being and that of our families and relatives. Those feeling unwell or are sick should stay at home, see a doctor, and avoid visiting. As crowds are expected at Choa Chu Kang Cemetery and government-managed columbaria during the Qing Ming period, visitors are requested to:    Minimise the family size visiting to two pax per household, with not more than eight pax per group;  Not bring elderly family members and young children;  Not eat and drink, or prolong their stay at the facilities;  Avoid crowding around the prayer and joss paper burning areas at the columbaria;  Keep a safe distance of at least 1 metre from other visitors, and wear a mask at all times; and  Carpool and register their vehicles if they intend to drive and park at Mandai Columbarium on peak days.""    http://archive.today/2021.03.08-190310/https://www.nea.gov.sg/media/news/advisories/index/public-advisory-on-safe-distancing-measures-at-government-cemetery-and-columbaria-for-qing-ming-festival

Authorities have placed Dili under lockdown through 23:59 March 15 due to COVID-19 concerns following the discovery of two cases in the capital. Residents must stay at home, except for urgent medical assistance, purchase essential goods and services, or travel to work for employees that must be onsite. All gatherings, including religious services, are banned during the lockdown. Officials have restricted almost all travel, including air and maritime transport, from the city. Exceptions are possible for safety, public health, or humanitarian reasons. Increased security is likely to enforce restrictions; police could erect checkpoints on main entry points to and from the capital. Significant business disruptions are likely.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314080531/https://crisis24.garda.com/insights/risk-alerts/wip1001271301/timor-leste-authorities-lock-down-dili-through-2359-march-15-due-to-covid-19-concerns

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Timor-Leste? Yes. At the time of this update, Timorese citizens and foreign nationals who are referred by a doctor for COVID-19 testing can obtain testing at the National Hospital, free of charge. Those seeking to test or experiencing COVID-19-like symptoms should call 119. COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee through the National Hospital for those needing COVID-free certification for international travel. Test results in English can be obtained directly from the National Health Laboratory or can be sent via email. Timor-Leste’s COVID-19 testing conditions are current as of the time of this update. Fees and services are subject to change; therefore, please confirm pricing when scheduling an appointment. 'The Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) announced that the Fall-Winter COVID-19 Prevention Program, originally scheduled to be effective from December 1, 2020, to February 28, 2021, would be adjusted and continue to be implemented on and after March 1, 2021, in response to the severity of COVID-19 globally and the continued occurrence of imported cases in Taiwan. The CECC urged the general public and healthcare facilities to cooperate with the Fall-Winter COVID-19 Prevention Program.    The main aspects of this program are listed below.    A. Border quarantine: all travelers coming to Taiwan and transit passengers are required to provide a COVID-19 RT-PCR test report issued within 3 days prior to the flight schedule time before boarding the flight to Taiwan;    B. Community prevention: the mandatory mask-wearing rule continues to be enforced in eight types of venues, and violators who refuse to comply after being advised will be penalized according to laws;    C. Medical response: strengthen case reporting and specimen collection procedures, and continue adopting surveillance indicators.'    https://archive.vn/NshmF

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? [Yes]  Before any intercity or interstate travel, all passengers using public means of transport (buses, taxis, trains, planes, ships, etc.) must complete an online health declaration (choose “For domestic move declaration”). Individuals traveling from any areas identified by the Vietnamese government as an “outbreak area”, particularly in Hai Duong, Quang Ninh, and Hai Phong may be sent to centralized quarantine facilities or required to self-quarantine at home for 14 – 21 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316021309/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

""Individuals traveling from any areas identified by the Vietnamese government as an “outbreak area”, particularly in Hai Duong, Quang Ninh, and Hai Phong may be sent to centralized quarantine facilities or required to self-quarantine at home for 14 – 21 days, depending on local authorities’ risk evaluation.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322235108/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

""The MOF recently proposed the Government to continue adopting tax deferral and land rental payment for businesses and household in 2021 with total value of VND 115 trillion, given Covid-19 has continued to weigh on business and production, in particular on the tourism and transport sectors. In which, VAT for firms is proposed to defer 5 months with total value of VND 68.8 trillion; CIT deferral would be allowed for 3 months in Q1-2 with total value of VND 40.5 trillion; deferral of PIT and VAT for households, and land rental payment are expected to reach VND 1.3 and 4.4 trillion, respectively.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323004626/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

As of March 6, there are 2 active cases, therefore Vanuatu has entered Scenario 2A:  No stay-at-home directive is in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316032247/https://covid19.gov.vu/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316033840/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of March 6, there are 2 active cases, therefore Vanuatu has entered Scenario 2A:  No restrictions on internal movement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316032247/https://covid19.gov.vu/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316033840/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry into Vanuatu must be approved by the Director of Immigration and fall within one of the following:  Vanuatu Citizens, Permanent Resident (physically reside in Vanuatu for the last 3 years), Foreigners with valid Residency permit issued before April 2020, Business owners with a valid residency visa, Dependents of the valid residency visa holders who are currently in Vanuatu, Partners must have a valid residency or Special Category Visa.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316033840/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210310181202/https://immigration.gov.vu/index.php/news-updates/travel-notice
Government public information campaign is in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316032247/https://covid19.gov.vu/

Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain government-paid or government-subsidized testing services at the Port Vila Central Hospital.  The testing policy in Vanuatu is that only people with symptoms (such as a fever, shortness of breath, cough and respiratory illness) who have travelled internationally within 14 days, or came in contact with a confirmed case, can be tested. If suspected by a clinician, some additional people can be included for testing. There is a restriction on the number of tests available internationally, therefore not everyone in the community can be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316033840/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316035648/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/questions-answers

Two new confirmed cases were repatriates (travelling from Papua New Guinea) and were detected through routine day 5 quarantine testing. Following the identification of these two cases, no close contacts were identified in Vanuatu. Based on syndromic data available to date, there is no evidence of sporadic cases, clusters of cases or community transmission.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316035819/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/surveillance

The Government of Vanuatu only recommend masks to the following: Health workers and people conducting health screenings, Individuals caring for a person with COVID-19, Individuals who have COVID-19 symptoms who can't avoid contact with others.  ""Because masks are in short supply, everyone is better off if they are reserved for those who actually require them, such as those who can't avoid exposure to people who are or may be infected.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316035648/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/questions-answers

""The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine has been listed by WHO for emergency use and will be used in Vanuatu. The approval process for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine in Vanuatu follows the usual high standards for the regulation of vaccines and is based on evidence of safety and efficacy provided by the results of clinical trials. The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine can be stored using the existing cold-chain used in Vanuatu for routine immunisation and doesn’t require specific freezers.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316040938/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/updates/press-releases/183-ministry-of-health-update-on-astrazeneca-vaccine-for-covid-19
